newsitem.title: USA: Cohen to seek cuts in fighter programs - officials.
newsitem.headline: Cohen to seek cuts in fighter programs - officials.

text.p: Defence Secretary William Cohen has decided to reduce by more than 300 the planned purchase of F-22 and FA-18E/F fighter jets in programmes under development by Lockheed Martin Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp., defence officials said on Wednesday.

But the cuts, which would be proposed to Congress this month under the Pentagon's cost-cutting quadrennial defence review, would not cancel Lockheed's F-22 "stealth" jet for the Air Force or McDonnell's FA-18E/F attack jet for the Navy.

Defence officials, who asked not to be identified, confirmed a Washington Post report that Cohen planned to recommend that the Air Force's previously planned purchase of 438 F-22s be reduced to 339. The cost of that programme under the full buy had been estimated at about $67 billion.

The QDR will recommend that Navy buys of the advanced FA- 18E/F be cut to about 785 or perhaps fewer from 1,000, the officials said. The Navy has planned to buy 1,000 of the aircraft for about $80 bilion by the year 2015.
Officials said there was no immediate indication that Cohen planned to seek cuts in the so-called Joint Strike Fighter programme which Lockheed Martin and Boeing Co. are competing to build.

The winning firm is expected to eventually build as many as 3,000 of the fighters for more than $170 billion in the next century. Variations of the jet would go to the Air Force, Navy, Marines and British Royal Navy and could be sold to other countries.
